The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used to overcome the host immune system. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the transcription factors. We show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that mediates nuclear import of cargo proteins. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune system and may provide a starting point for the development of new antiviral strategies. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses. This will have important implications for global food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. We use a statistical model to project the future variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 86% under 4 °C warming. This will have important implications for global food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. Our results also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores (LMH) partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which LMH partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level plant remains in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven LMH species in semiarid African savanna. Our results indicate that LMH partition food resources, even among species that are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for understanding the causes and consequences of LMH diversity in grasslands.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. We also assess the effects of loans relative to grants-based programs.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the elements is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. The study of presolar grains, which are found in meteorites, is one of the most promising approaches to understand the formation of the elements. We determined the ages of 40 presolar grains from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have a wide range of ages, from 3.9 Ma to 3 Ga, and are likely part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains have cosmogenic nuclides, which were produced by cosmic rays in the interstellar medium. The results indicate that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago, which is an important period in the history of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals and the extent to which these factors are universal. We find that the ability to provide for offspring, either through provisioning or allonursing, is a strong predictor of reproductive output. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a significant finding because it suggests that the evolution of domestication and allonursing may have been a key factor in the success of mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the neurotoxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major advance in the treatment of MSA and other α-synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of communication channels. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, allowing for rapid communication of information throughout the endothelium. The network is also designed to be highly dynamic, allowing for rapid changes in response to changes in the environment. These properties make the endothelium an important player in health and disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and data on the pandemic are critical for understanding and responding to the crisis. The COVIDcast API is a data product that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary indicators that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These indicators are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying software packages, and are described in this paper. The data are expected to be useful for many purposes, including tracking the pandemic, monitoring public behavior, and supporting epidemiological research.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. The activation gate closes the selectivity filter, and the selectivity filter is the main determinant of the channel’s conductance. We have identified a Threonine residue as the key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have shown that this Threonine residue is crucial for the C-type inactivation gating and the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. Finally, we have shown that the selectivity filter can be collapsed by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a critical role in human health. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are poorly understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identified 146 genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for diverse types of natural products, including antibiotics, bacteriocins, and styrylpyrones. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This work represents a first step toward the discovery of natural products from anaerobic gut fungi.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We found that high-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the availability of materials and manufacturing processes. Here, we propose a strategy to synthesize multifunctional mechanical devices with desired behaviors by using a digital design approach and multimaterial fabrication. The devices are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors and seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional devices with complex behaviors and can be further applied to design multifunctional devices with dynamic behaviors. This work provides a general approach to design multifunctional mechanical devices with desired behaviors. It can be extended to design multifunctional devices with dynamic behaviors. This work can be extended to design multifunctional devices with dynamic behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in the human body. In particular, IGF2BP1 mediates the developmental silencing of the beta-globin gene and the up-regulation of the gamma-globin gene. These findings suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in the human body.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. Ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the mechanisms underlying the resistance of cancer cells to ferroptosis are not well understood. Here, we show that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also show that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1, and that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1. Finally, we demonstrate that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells and suggest a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are widely used in clinical practice, but the mechanisms of their action on vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor system in VSMCs, which is a key regulator of vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension and heart failure. However, our data also suggest that LCCBs may be harmful in patients with advanced age or cardiovascular disease, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older forest bird populations. We also show that the policy has not been effective in halting the decline of early forest bird populations. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train than other popular architectures. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are unknown. We compared the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. Participants reading an LE-eBook took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is marked by a cooling of ∼3 °C in the Northern Hemisphere. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. We further show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoantibodies, and that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to show that beetles diversified in the Carboniferous, a period of high beetle diversity, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers were key to the Mesozoic diversification of specialized herbivorous beetles. These results suggest that beetles diversified in a world dominated by angiosperms, and that the evolution of specialized herbivory was driven by the acquisition of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the maintenance of culture than for its enhancement.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is protective whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. However, the mechanisms underlying this association are not well understood. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of complement component C1q in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased levels of senescent astrocytes in the hippocampus. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory that allows us to study the crystallization process of the Earth. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase is the first nucleus, followed by the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core and its structure. They also suggest that the crystallization process of the inner core is still active, which is important for understanding the dynamics of the core. Our findings are expected to have a significant impact on the study of the inner core and the origin of the Earth.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well established, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also show increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, we know surprisingly little about how the human brain processes language. Here, we show that deep learning models that have revolutionized the understanding of vision and speech processing in the last few years also provide a powerful lens through which to view the human brain’s processing of language. We find that these models can predict nearly all of the brain’s explainable variance when decoding responses to sentences in the scanner and can predict the next word in a sentence with strong accuracy. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that deep learning models may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain’s processing of language in health and disease. (Read more)

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not intrinsic to DL but rather a consequence of the difficulty of training deep neural networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where no algorithm can train a neural network that is stable in the sense that it is accurate to a given precision with high probability. This result is a first step toward understanding the conditions under which stable neural networks can be trained. We also introduce a new class of neural networks that are stable and prove that they are optimal in terms of the number of layers needed to achieve a given accuracy. Our results have implications for the design of neural networks and the development of training algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It is also a major source of public confusion and anxiety. In the midst of this crisis, scientists have argued that the public’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major contributing factor. They have cited a classic experiment published 45 years prior to the first case of COVID-19. Despite its critical design flaws, this experiment is now widely cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses the flaws of the experiment and the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and the causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, where leprosy is endemic, and compared it with that of the type strain of M. leprae. We found that the two organisms are very similar, and that the genome of M. lepromatosis, a leprosy pathogen that is rarely found in endemic areas, is more similar to that of M. leprae than to that of M. leprae. This suggests that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the ancestral form of the pathogen and may be neuropathogenic. Our findings also suggest that the two leprosy pathogens have been relatively stable over time and that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This is important because the development of new drugs and vaccines is difficult, and the understanding of the evolution of the pathogens may help us to predict the future of leprosy. The dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a central open problem in quantum science. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is the one developed by our group, which is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. We describe the development of this vaccine and its potential for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the spread of infectious diseases. Our results are relevant to the current COVID-19 pandemic, as well as to the development of effective control measures for future epidemics.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known story, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncogene. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the controversial role of TRAP1 in cancer. It also suggests that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes, such as cell motility. They are also disassembled by a protein family called actin depolymerizing factors (ADF)/cofilins. However, how ADF/cofilins are able to disassemble actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilins are able to enhance the severing of filaments by a mechanism that is based on the filament’s mechanical state. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilins’ ability to disassemble highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanism may be of general importance in the disassembly of filaments in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose and glucose remain unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose and may contribute to the obesogenic environment in which we live.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the island. Finally, we find that the genetic structure is not only a consequence of the admixture but also of the geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a highly heterogeneous way. This is important to understand the origin of the island and the settlement of Africa.

It also suggests that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms. They also suggest that people may be influenced by the emotions of others without their awareness.

The ribosome is a highly complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that are translated. The mRNA sequence can also be modified posttranscriptionally, and these modifications can have profound effects on protein synthesis. We have developed a system to study the effects of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. We find that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings suggest that mRNA modifications can have a significant impact on protein synthesis, and that the ribosome can be a major contributor to mRNA modification dynamics. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the interplay between mRNA modifications and translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or of outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been studied in cell culture, but the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon have not been elucidated. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at core body temperature than at nasal cavity temperature. This results in higher levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs, which are required for efficient inhibition of rhinovirus replication. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the environment in order to survive. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is required for attachment to surfaces, and promotes long-term attachment by amplifying the initial response. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is likely to be used by other bacteria to sense their environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly increasing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, including the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is very high, and that the risk of exceeding the regulatory threshold levels is also very high. This study highlights the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to many animal species, including deer, and may persist in the wild. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer in the United States. We also show that the virus has spread among deer, highlighting the urgent need for a proactive “One Health” approach to understand the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of the proliferation of large dams, and the solutions that are needed. We propose a framework for the sustainable development of hydropower that can be used by the hydropower industry, governments, and civil society.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is associated with a chronic, systemic immune response. However, the origin of this response is unclear, and it is not known whether it is triggered by the presence of amyloid plaques or by the accumulation of soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) within the brain. We demonstrate that neurons are the source of a variety of proinflammatory molecules, even in the absence of extracellular Aβ plaques. We also show that the extent of this response correlates with the extent of microglial activation and the presence of Aβ-laden macrophages. Finally, we identify a unique inflammatory profile within the human brain, which is vulnerable to AD, suggesting that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a primary source of the systemic immune response in AD. These findings provide insight into the complex interplay between neurons and the immune system in AD pathogenesis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry and the spread of agriculture in the ancient Near East. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study also provides a new perspective on the spread of agriculture and animal husbandry in the ancient Near East. The results of our survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant show a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. This increase is likely to be related to the spread of agriculture and animal husbandry in the region. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to fold through a native-like intermediate. We find that the intermediate is not the only step in the folding process. We also find that the intermediate is not the last step in the folding process. These results suggest that the folding of a large protein is a complex process that involves multiple distinct steps. This is consistent with the view that the folding of a protein is a complex process that involves multiple distinct steps.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular conditions that lead to the formation of Np4 and the mechanisms by which they are decapped remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decapsulate Np4-capped RNAs, also removes Np4-capped 5′ termini in a manner distinct from its normal substrate specificity. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ termini by a mechanism that is unique among the enzymes that we know of that decapsulate RNAs, and it has the potential to affect the rate at which Np4-capped RNAs are degraded. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although the immune response is essential for the resolution of infection, it can also lead to severe tissue damage and organ failure. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in reducing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly marine. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system adjusts its dynamics to maintain a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, a self-similarity of the activity, and a correlation between the activity and the system’s parameters. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanical properties of diamond and to develop methods to control its mechanical properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or demetallized, by applying strain. This work provides a new method to control the mechanical properties of diamond. It also provides a foundation for the development of diamond-based devices. This work is expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

The discovery of antifungal peptides is a major advance in the fight against fungal diseases. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the mechanisms of action are not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, and demonstrate that it is a potent fungicide against plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide has a broad-spectrum antifungal activity and can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and a strategy for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungicide. This will be of great benefit to the global food security and the environment. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical interface in which the contributions of each partner are critical to reproductive success. However, the extent to which the female contributes to the male’s reproductive output is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female contributes to the male’s reproductive output by providing proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies that will elucidate the extent to which the female contributes to the male’s reproductive output and the extent to which the male contributes to the female’s reproductive output. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of VWF mutations, explaining pathophysiology. This suggests that the force-dependent pathway is the dominant mechanism of VWF activation. This is the first time that a force-dependent pathway has been observed in a protein. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a major step forward in the study of human-associated viruses, and provides a comprehensive resource for the field. The database is freely available, and can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI processes. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but leads to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The most widely accepted estimate of surface temperature in the Archean, the earliest period of Earth’s history, is 70 ± 15 °C. This estimate is based on isotopic evidence, however, and is subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the accuracy of the isotopic record, the influence of diagenesis or metamorphism on the record, and the depositional environment. We present a method for reconstructing the temperature of ancient Earth surface environments based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in cells and are regulated by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the major barriers to treatment is the ability of the parasite to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the host cell in which the parasite develops. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a key adhesin, EBA175, to bind to the red cell surface and alter the biophysical properties of the cell. We show that this interaction leads to a reduction in the energy barrier to invasion and thus a major change in the invasion process. This finding has major implications for our understanding of malaria parasite invasion and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This is a major paradigm shift in our understanding of the invasion process. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is difficult to use diamond in applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be closed, by applying strain. This opens up a new way to control the properties of diamond. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and the bandgap can be opened, by applying tensile strain. This can be used to control the phase transition from diamond to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work can help to develop diamond-based applications in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may help develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus outbreaks. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly increases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity and is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the construction of language representations in the brain.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer, and its dysregulation is associated with many human diseases. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that regulate redundant genes and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), which project to LH GABA neurons. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH GABA neurons or dopamine neurons in the VTA or SNc. These results suggest that LH GABA neurons are downstream of dopamine neurons and may promote overeating.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil would revolutionize agriculture. However, the symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria is complex and difficult to control, and the potential benefits of this process have not been fully realized. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, using a synthetic signaling system between the plant and the bacteria. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a significant impact on agriculture, as well as on the development of synthetic biology. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, deforestation alerts are rarely detected by the communities most directly affected by deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s short duration. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse, and many animals have evolved to listen to the world in ways that are not possible for the ears of other animals. We show that the ears of the orb-weaving spider, Larinioides sclopetarius, are not constrained by the organism’s body but are extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider’s outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function provides unique features for studying acoustic flow detection and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of how animals can evolve to listen to the world in ways that are not possible for the ears of other animals. The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuel and other anthropogenic sources. We find that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The availability of safe and efficacious vaccines is critical to ending the pandemic. We report a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that is well-established, proven, and can be manufactured at large scale. This vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is highly immunogenic and can be presented on a virus-like particle. This variant is suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing, minimizing its manufacturing cost. This vaccine candidate can be produced at a large scale, which is critical for global access. This work provides a potential solution to the global access challenge of COVID-19 vaccines. It is a simple, scalable, and cost-effective vaccine that can be manufactured at large scale. The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are expressed in the developing nervous system. They are implicated in the development of the nervous system in mammals. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and may lead to the development of zebrafish ALKAL mutants as a model for neural crest development and neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been difficult to reconstruct. We present a large dataset of ancient plague genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results suggest that the plague lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the 14th century CE was not a single lineage but rather a small population that spread across Eurasia, with a rapid expansion of the plague form adapted to the flea vector. These results provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to its vector. (Show more)

This work examined the extent to which men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—predicted support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, SOC sequestration in agricultural systems is often limited by the loss of soil organic matter (SOM) to the soil-borne mineral phase. We show that soil health management practices can increase the amount of SOM that remains in the soil-dwelling organic matter pool. We found that soil health management practices that incorporate legumes and manure into annual cropping systems can increase the amount of SOM that remains in the soil-dwelling particulate and microbial organic matter pools. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon in agricultural landscapes. This is an important finding given that grasslands cover 30% of the global land area and are the most rapidly disappearing ecosystem on the planet. Our findings also have implications for the design of future agricultural research and policy.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover and used this to rank the zoonotic potential of 887 viruses from wild animals. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery efforts and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for the services they provide. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany dating to the Early Medieval period. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men in this group is similar to that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that women in this group had visible characteristics that differed from modern women. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. We also found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings have implications for the development of MERS-CoV countermeasures. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA from 464 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Our findings suggest that pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate epidemics.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the unique properties of lagging strand synthesis in humans. They also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a key factor in the development of cancer. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by RNA polymerases. In the laboratory, RNA polymerases have been used to synthesize RNA molecules, but the ability to replicate RNA, to amplify RNA, and to synthesize functional RNA molecules has been limited to a few specialized enzymes. Here, we report the development of a general RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify RNA, and convert RNA into DNA. Thus, it can serve as the basis for the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. We demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide metabolite that is secreted and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with other microbes. This knowledge may be useful in the development of antifungal and antibacterial agents. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is rare on Earth. The tridymite in the Martian mudstone is well-crystalline, indicating a high formation temperature. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, indicating a common source. The other crystalline minerals are detrital, indicating a common source region. The amorphous material is precipitated from variable aqueous solutions, indicating a complex history of fluid infiltration and diagenesis. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not well adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a recently identified subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are unknown. We found that Th17 cells could not induce colitis in recipients of a Th17 transfer, indicating that they require the help of additional cells. We also found that Th17 cells could support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This dual mechanism of action may explain the ability of Th17 cells to induce both the development of disease and spontaneous remission.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary movement. The disease is progressive, and death occurs within 3 to 5 y. Accurate disease modeling, identifying disease mechanisms, and developing therapeutics is urgently needed. We now report a method to rapidly convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This approach will enable the study of disease mechanisms and development of new therapies. It will also enable the study of the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases. This will be of great benefit to ALS patients and their families. (Show more)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen virulence and transmission. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick I. scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota and enhance pathogen transmission. They also suggest that IAFGP may be a promising target for the development of novel tick control strategies. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan. However, the study of the evolution of the avian tail has been hindered by the limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians. Here, we describe a basal member of the clade Pygostylia (Jinguofortis) that adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group.
