Our results show that the evolution of the avian tail was more complex than previously thought, with the mosaic evolution of both plesiomorphic and derived avian tail features. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail. (Show more)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

The evolution of color in animals is one of the most important and fascinating topics in biology. The presence of blue-green colors in vertebrates is a relatively recent phenomenon, and the biochemical basis of this phenomenon is poorly understood. We show that the presence of blue-green colors in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this evolution is linked to the presence of a class of serpins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also provides a molecular explanation for the presence of blue-green colors in anurans, and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is a key factor in the development of metastases and resistance to therapy. We report that hypoxia induces expression of an m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. This results in an increase in the number of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for metastasis and resistance to therapy. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment used to make them has been a long-standing mystery. This paper presents a method to identify the animal origin of parchment, which can be used to settle the controversy. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by mass spectrometry analysis. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of the parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles. The results suggest that the use of fetal animals was not necessary to produce the first pocket Bibles.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the extinction, the rapid reorganization of the carbon cycle, and the persistence of decamillenial to millennial level fluctuations in the carbon cycle during the postextinction interval suggest that the extinction was triggered by a combination of factors. The age model developed here will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The results will also establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This will be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing extinction event.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response and inflammation. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and multifactorial, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive NF-κB activation and subsequent inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our findings suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for developing vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the host receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, and the fusion peptide. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has led to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the host cell. This study provides a structural basis for the increased transmissibility of the D614G mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003, and a decline in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our projections highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of the disease and its consequences.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we propose a pressure-dependent electronegativity and chemical hardness scale, which can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena under pressure. We show that the proposed scale is a powerful tool for predicting and explaining the chemistry of elements under pressure. We also show that the proposed scale can be used to predict the chemistry of compounds, which is a major goal of chemistry.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can release large amounts of carbon into the atmosphere. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain, and the role of human ignitions is not well understood. We show that human ignitions can reduce the warming caused by increasing greenhouse gas emissions. This is because human ignitions can reduce the amount of carbon released from forests and other terrestrial ecosystems, thereby reducing the rate of warming. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by reducing ignitions, although this comes with risks of more extreme fires. Our study highlights the importance of human ignitions in driving future fire regimes and the need to understand the effects of climate change on ignitions.

The provision of nutrients to microbes associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their symbiotic communities. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, which is used to produce bioluminescence in the host. We demonstrate that the glycan is provided only at dusk, when the host is ready to receive it, and that its catabolism is required for the host’s own metabolism and for the host–microbe interaction. This glycan-mediated regulation of the host–microbe interaction may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the health of their symbionts.

The study of topics in text is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with word embedding to identify topics in text. Our method, discourse atom topic modeling (DATM), is motivated by the need to model the structure of text data, such as the NVDRS, and to identify gender biases in the topics. We illustrate the method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. We expect it to be useful in many domains, including social science, medicine, and law. It can be used to identify latent patterns in text data, to model the structure of text data, and to identify gender biases in the topics. It can also be used to generate new text.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the bacterium originated, were favorable for the persistence of the rodent reservoir, which was responsible for the recurrent outbreaks of the plague in Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the result of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This finding challenges the traditional view of the plague as a single event, and suggests that the spread of the disease was the result of a complex interplay between climate, human behavior, and the movement of pathogens. (Show more)

The asteroid mass mortality (i.e., sea star wasting disease) is one of the most dramatic events in the history of the Northeast Pacific Coast. The disease has been associated with a virus, but the identity of the virus has been unknown. Here, we present evidence that the virus is a member of the Parvoviridae, a family of viruses that are known to cause disease in other marine organisms. The virus is likely to be the cause of the asteroid mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that the antibodies can achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that the antibody can be used as a tool for the study of the biology of AML. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that the antibody can be used as a tool for the study of the biology of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the island. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the history of human colonization of the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for future studies on the genomic diversity of Madagascar. This study is also a good example of how to use a grid-based approach to sample genomic data across a large area. This approach is particularly useful for large areas with complex topography and/or large population sizes.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that interacts with the glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, GlpD, and increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the RNA also interacts with two other metabolic enzymes, cadA and galE, and that the interaction with the carbon utilization enzymes competes with the interaction with the sRNA. The interaction with the carbon utilization enzymes is important for the growth of the bacteria in galactose medium. The interaction with the sRNA is important for the growth of the bacteria in glycerol medium. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete with each other. This is an example of a protein that is encoded by an RNA and that has both a translation function and a base-pairing function.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate that the probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results suggest that crop experts can be used as a powerful network of “people as sensors” to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This can help farmers plan their production and mitigate the impact of crop anomalies. It can also help governments plan agricultural policies and mitigate the impact of crop anomalies on food security.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. We propose an alternative view where memory is supported by a form of intrinsic plasticity that reduces firing rates. This adaptive change in excitability is dependent on experience and can be used to store information on multiple timescales. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We provide a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This information is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes are central questions in biology. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plants, and the molecular signature of this process is poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle, and that the loss of function is accompanied by a relaxation of purifying selection. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This process may have led to the emergence of new rate equilibria, which are reflected in the molecular evolution of plastid genes. These findings have implications for the evolution of other organelles and for the origin of life. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for policy makers and the public, as it provides a quantitative estimate of the risk of future droughts in SSA. It also highlights the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to reduce the risk of future droughts.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal, with its precise time of creation indelibly etched in history, demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed under conditions that are not natural and that the search for new quasicrystal-forming systems is not limited to nature. This work also demonstrates the potential of nuclear testing as a source of scientific discovery.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This study reveals that the oxygen-sensitive cyclase enzyme in oxygenic phototrophs is composed of three classes, based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the oxygen-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms. (Bacterio)chlorophylls are the most abundant photosynthetic pigments on Earth, and the evolution of this reaction is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS), and is also a common feature in many other neurological disorders. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of cell survival and apoptosis. However, the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remains unclear. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes exacerbates neuroinflammation in a phase-specific manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm conditions has increased. We show that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions, and that additional warming will increase the probability of drought. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes is a major challenge. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a target for drug development. It also provides a general framework for understanding the functions of other genes that are involved in the same behavioral process. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) entry (SOCE) pathway is a key regulator of cellular physiology, but its pathophysiological role in human disease is poorly understood. Here, we identify mutations in the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 and the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that cause congenital bleeding and myopathy, and demonstrate that these mutations cause constitutive activation of the SOCE pathway in vitro and in vivo. Our findings expand our understanding of the pathophysiology of congenital bleeding and myopathy, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the study of spreading neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The identification of the immunologically privileged sites in bats is of great importance for understanding the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats to humans. Here, we identified the submandibular salivary gland as a highly immunologically privileged site in bats, which is characterized by the high concentration of immunosuppressant protein (MTX) and the absence of the aminopeptidase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H). MTX inhibited the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitated viral infection. MTX had no effect on the LTA4H function of antiinflammation and maintained high stability. These findings provide deeper insight into the immunologically privileged sites in bats and support the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections in bats and humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer growth in mice, and that the cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. We also show that the cancer cells of one type of lymphoma are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work has implications for cancer treatment and for the design of small-molecule inhibitors of other enzymes that convert one-carbon units.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons in the spinal cord and brain. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including superaggregation-prone proteins such as superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the transactive response DNA binding protein 43 (TDP-43), and the fused in sarcoma (FUS) protein. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the coaggregating proteins are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners, suggesting that they are metastable in motor neurons. Thus, the metastable nature of the coaggregating proteins may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases in which superaggregation is a feature. This may be a general property of proteins that are prone to aggregation, and thus may be a useful target for therapeutic intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for quantum simulation of many-body physics, including quantum chemistry, quantum chemistry, and quantum simulation of condensed matter physics. The photonic crystal system is also a promising platform for quantum simulation of many-body physics, including quantum chemistry, quantum chemistry, and quantum simulation of condensed matter physics.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that colonized the shallow waters of the Cretaceous period. The study of the aquatic flowering plants Montsechia and Ceratophyllum, described here, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolutionary history of viruses that have been around for millions of years. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which are from human remains that are up to 6.9 thousand years old. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a well-known phenomenon, but the causes are still debated. We show that the observed acceleration is consistent with climate change, and we estimate the rate of sea level rise that would be expected under the most recent IPCC assessment.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across measures of pain, including self-report, medical records, and the presence of opioid prescriptions. It is also seen across measures of the burden of pain, including the number of days spent in pain, the number of pain-related days missed from work, and the number of pain-related days missed from all activities. The increase in pain is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The ability to study the structure and dynamics of chemical intermediates in enzyme catalysis is a key goal in enzymology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to study the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the intermediate, including the location of the protonation states of the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS-CoV infection, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment initiated 12 h postinoculation provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The availability of effective antiviral treatments is critical to reduce the burden of viral pneumonia. This study provides evidence that remdesivir may be effective in the treatment of MERS-CoV infection. It also provides a rationale for the testing of remdesivir in the context of a clinical

The provision of nutrients to microbes associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their symbiotic communities. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, which is used to produce bioluminescence in the host. We show that the glycan is provided only at dusk, when the host is ready to receive it, and that its catabolism is required for the host’s own metabolism and for the host–microbe interaction. This glycan-mediated regulation of the symbiont population and the host’s metabolism may be a common mechanism used by animals to control the health of their epithelial-associated microbiomes.

The suspension of students from school is a common and controversial practice. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which in turn bolsters the quality of teacher–student relationships and reduces suspensions. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still poorly understood. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on transcription. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The findings are expected to provide important mechanistic insights into the role of DNA alkylation in mutagenesis and cancer.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on these emissions, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that it may be possible to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices by changing the physical environment in which they make decisions. This is an important finding, as it suggests that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable dietary choices.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and show how each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also show how the surfaceome is remodeled in response to oncogene activation, and how this can be used to identify surface targets and combinations thereof for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. These studies suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a resource for the breast cancer community to identify surface targets and biomarkers for this disease. This work is a first step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the surfaceome in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout rates. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal adverse effects on electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to be highly infectious and to cause severe disease in some individuals. The molecular basis for the severity of the disease is unknown, but it is likely due to the virus’s ability to evade the host immune system. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be used to evade the host immune response. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the COVID-19 disease. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. This CRF is then taken up by the cortex and acts on the CRF receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular explanation for the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists could be developed as a treatment for cerebral edema. This could be particularly important in the case of hypoxic brain injury, which is a major cause of death and disability worldwide. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. It is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations that we find in our data. The fact that we have “cherry picked”—searched for the strongest associations—means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This paper describes some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. It is intended for statisticians and data scientists who are interested in the theory and practice of statistical inference.

The development of vascular ECs is a key step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of ECs is difficult to achieve in vitro, and the formation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vivo. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the development of vascular ECs from fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the development of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. This strategy can be applied to the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. This study also provides a new strategy for the development of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. This strategy can be applied to the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that the augmentor ligands of Alk and Ltk are essential for zebrafish pigment development. We demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the zebrafish eye and body coloration. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of augmentor ligands and their role in the development of the zebrafish pigment system. These findings may also have implications for the development of Alk inhibitors in cancer therapy. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in regulating insulin sensitivity has been well established, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired glucose homeostasis and β-cell function, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to infect a wide range of species, including humans, and are responsible for millions of deaths each year. The influenza A genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which is a unique feature among RNA viruses. This genome organization offers evolutionary advantages, but it also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA fragments of an influenza A virus. We show that this interaction is required for optimal viral replication and that it is sequence dependent. We also show that this interaction favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA fragments. Our results indicate that viral RNA fragments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings have implications for the evolution of influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, and obesity. The atheroprone environment is characterized by disturbed flow, oxidative stress, and inflammation. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This strategy may be applicable to the treatment of other athero-prone conditions.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the extent of wildfire in the United States. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the expansion of human-started wildfires has been the primary driver of the increase in wildfire activity. Actions to reduce the role of humans in increasing wildfire activity should be a focus of United States policy.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience larger improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically proximate to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvements. These findings provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our findings also suggest that physical improvements in neighborhoods are correlated with the presence of educated residents and with the physical attractiveness of the neighborhoods in which they live. These findings have implications for urban planning and for the study of the spatial distribution of human capital.

Natural repellents are a promising strategy for pest control, but the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain unknown. We identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated that Drosophila melanogaster dTRPγ ion channel is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents to mediate avoidance behavior. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The virus is also associated with a microcephaly syndrome, in which the head is smaller than normal. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus is highly contagious and that the time between infection and the production of infectious particles is short. We also show that the virus is cleared from the body relatively quickly, and that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can help guide the development of antiviral strategies for the treatment of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. One of the most severe impacts of climate change is the increasing frequency of mass bleaching events, which are characterized by a breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. We show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are a consequence of altered nutrient cycling within the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in the future. This may ultimately help us to conserve this unique and valuable ecosystem. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the host–microbe interaction. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor suppressor gene in the intestinal epithelium leads to the activation of a signaling pathway that disrupts the barrier function of the epithelium and alters the composition of the microbiome. We also show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response that stimulates tumor growth. Our results identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the activity of the intestinal epithelium and highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between tumorigenesis and host defense. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in cancer development and progression. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is not universal. We show that treatment of breast cancer cells with chemotherapy enhances the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1, which in turn enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in climate science. The recent discovery of a volcanic eruption at the start of the last deglaciation has led to a reevaluation of the climate system response to the largest volcanic eruption in the last 8,000 y. We show that the eruption of Mount Takahe, Antarctica, was the trigger for a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a rapid warming of the Southern Hemisphere, leading to the onset of the last deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity conservation. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to be sustainable and productive, and where conservation efforts should focus to protect biodiversity and food security. This information can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are responsible for the high capacity and low operating potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous Li-ion batteries.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury, and the mechanisms that control this loss of regenerative capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system can be restored.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and repaired, and it is essential for the normal development of all eukaryotic organisms. In humans and mice, hotspots of recombination are known to occur in promoter regions of genes, and in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, recombination is largely defined by binding sites of this protein. Here, we describe recombination hotspots in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, which are interspersed among cold regions of low recombination. We also show that recombination is more likely to terminate in exons than in introns within genes. These results suggest that hotspots in flowering plants may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. They also provide a model for studying the evolution of recombination in a wild plant population. This work may be of interest to evolutionary biologists, geneticists, and plant biologists.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of different brain regions fluctuates over time. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a number of topographically organized networks, which are hypothesized to reflect functional properties of the brain. However, the validity of these networks has not been directly tested. Here, we show that the dominant network in the resting brain is topographically similar to the default mode network, and that this network is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dominant network in the resting brain is associated with reduced brain activity during cognitive tasks, and that this abnormality is present early in the disease. These results provide a direct test of the validity of resting state networks, and suggest that they may be used to monitor the progression of disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for translation. We describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and is found on pre-mRNAs and mature mRNAs. This suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate mRNA stability and translation. The NAD-RNA cap is found on subsets of mRNAs, and could be a target for posttranscriptional regulation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). The epigenetic mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not known. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood monocytes and in whole blood are associated with glycemia in the DCCT, and that these associations persist for several years during the follow-up of the DCCT. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has a poor prognosis. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a target in the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals it produces. These chemicals are synthesized in the fruit, and the composition of the volatile bouquet is determined by the biosynthetic pathways that produce them. The pathways that produce the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit are not known, and the only known pathway for the production of these compounds in other plants is in the tobacco plant. Here, we describe the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that produces a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of thermal tolerance in determining the impacts of climate change on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from freely moving mice in an open field, and we found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial memory, are topographically segregated from other neurons in MEC. These data suggest that grid cells form a distinct network from those of border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These findings have implications for understanding the neural basis of navigation and memory. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is able to synchronize the flowering of host and parasite plants. This study illustrates how a parasite may use flowering as a means to synchronize its own reproduction with that of its host, likely optimizing its fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra form highly unusual arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a unique view of the dopamine-containing nigral system and its relationship to the striatum. It also suggests that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust signal of felt connection. This signal is used by people to gauge how connected they feel to others, and by others to gauge how connected two people are. This signal is fast (milliseconds) and honest (people can’t control it), and it is used by people to gauge how connected they feel to others, and by others to gauge how connected two people are. This provides a mechanism for people to gauge connection, and for others to gauge connection, without conscious awareness.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and are located in the wall of the right atrium. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia that is associated with an increased risk of stroke. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for the generation of the heartbeat. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SANCs by controlling the content of Ca2+ in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, the intracellular Ca2+ store. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atrial fibrillation. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex mixture of lipids, which are important for the regulation of many cellular processes. The lipidome of macrophages is also affected by the treatment of phenylketonuria patients with tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor that is used to treat mild forms of phenylketonuria. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin affects the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin affects the expression of genes involved in the immune response. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. We propose an alternative view where memory is supported by a form of intrinsic plasticity that reduces firing rates. This adaptive change in excitability is dependent on experience and can be used to store information on multiple timescales. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plant cells is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

Nutrient pollution is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient loads has been overlooked. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries are more important than previously thought, delivering ∼20% of the daily nutrient loads to the lake. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may be a significant source of nutrients that fuel algal blooms in nearshore areas. Our results highlight the need to expand nutrient management efforts to small tributaries, which could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that provides work to the system only in rare, favorable combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the system exhibits a strong tendency to concentrate in states that are extremized with respect to the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the phenomenon of critical slowing down, which is a well-known feature of many physical systems that are driven out of equilibrium.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the NMDA receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies can change the way the brain is wired, and that this can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We use a dynamic model of the brain to show that the key parameters that control the brain’s electrical activity are changed by the antibodies. We then show that the same changes in the brain’s electrical activity can be tolerated in a model of the brain without the antibodies. These findings offer mechanistic insights into how antibodies can cause seizures. They also suggest that the brain’s electrical activity may be a useful biomarker of the effects of antibodies. This could help to guide treatment decisions. It may also help to identify the mechanisms by which antibodies cause seizures in other autoimmune encephalitis. This could lead to the development of new treatments.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbations is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon over the seafloor and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in seafloor anoxia and to enhanced thermocline stratification and nutrient fluxes within an icehouse. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of abrupt climate change and the potential for future climate change. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is the largest buyer of deforestation-free palm oil, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of palm oil. However, certification has no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection. Our results suggest that certification is not reducing deforestation in the most critical areas, such as peatlands, and may be contributing to the expansion of oil palm into these areas. We recommend that certification be expanded to forested regions, and that strict requirements be imposed to avoid all peat, and that certification be accompanied by routine monitoring of clearly defined forest loss.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is conserved from bacteria to humans. It is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the movement of vesicles to the plasma membrane and the formation of the fusion pore. The exocyst complex is involved in a variety of physiological processes, including plant growth and development, and the regulation of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases. We discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential drug target for human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce the sex phenotype. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the multiple alleles interact to produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized and degraded by reactive oxygen species. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP) reduces the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduces cell death in cell-based experiments. These findings indicate that Fe levels in the retina promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. This interpretation is supported by experiments showing that DFP decreases the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduces cell death in cell-based experiments. These results have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Am J Pathol. 2016;186:2781–2790)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the study of how they have evolved to feed on different prey types is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization in predators has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with morphological and functional optimizations. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is not a dead end, but rather a case of morphological modularity that has allowed the evolution of specialization on different prey types. Our findings help understand how specialization has shaped present-day food webs, and how morphological innovations have allowed predators to diversify their diets.

The human hand is a remarkable adaptation that has allowed us to succeed as a species. However, the evolution of the modern human hand is poorly understood because of a lack of fossil evidence from the time of our divergence from other apes. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present in a Middle Pleistocene hominin from East Africa. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer growth in mice, and that the cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. We also show that the cancer cells of one type of lymphoma are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work has implications for cancer treatment, and for the development of new metabolic inhibitors. (Simplified version)

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with an increasing number of people suffering from undernutrition and a growing number suffering from overweight and obesity. In response, strategies to improve food and nutrition security have been promoted, which have focused on increasing agricultural production. However, little attention has been paid to the role of natural landscapes such as forests in improving people’s diets. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake, and that forest fragmentation can increase consumption of these foods. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and health.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest land animals that walked Earth. This study shows that the weight of farm machinery has increased subsoil compaction risk, with the risk of subsoil compaction now affecting 20% of arable land. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods, the largest land animals that walked Earth, would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm machinery, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. It also suggests that the ecological strategies of sauropods may have been a response to the risk of subsoil compaction. (Show more)
